titlestmt.subtitle: A Finding Aid to the Jane Teller Papers, 1911-1991, in the Archives of American Art
titlestmt.author: by Eden Orelove

publicationstmt.publisher: Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution

profiledesc.creation: Finding aid encoded by Eden Orelove on October 13, 2011

did.head: Collection Overview

repository.label: Repository:
repository.corpname: Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution

did.abstract: The papers of printmaker and sculptor Jane Teller measure 8.3 linear feet and date from 1911 to 1991. The papers include biographical materials, correspondence, business records, notes, writings, three sketchbooks, sketches and prints, five scrapbooks, printed material, subject files, photographs, sound and video recordings, and motion picture film.

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: The Jane Teller papers were donated by Jane Teller in 1990 and in 1991 by Walter Teller, widower of Jane Teller.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: The collection was arranged by Jean Fitzgerald in 1994. Eden Orelove created the finding aid in 2011.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Jane Teller papers, 1911-1991. Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution.

accessrestrict.head: Restrictions on Access
accessrestrict.p: Use of original papers requires an appointment. Use of archival audiovisual recordings with no duplicate access copy requires advance notice.

userestrict.head: Ownership and Literary Rights
userestrict.p: The Jane Teller papers are owned by the Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution. Literary rights as possessed by the donor have been dedicated to public use for research, study, and scholarship. The collection is subject to all copyright laws.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Jane Teller (1911-1990) worked as a printmaker and sculptor primarily in New Jersey. She specialized in working with wood and studied at the Rochester Institute of Technology, Skidmore College, and Barnard College. She also attended Federal Works Progress Administration (W.P.A.) classes in New York City, studying sculpture with Aaron J. Goodelman and wood carving with Karl Nielson. She later studied welding in the studio of Ibram Lassaw. She was also a lifelong friend of photographer Aaron Siskind. In 1960, she was awarded the Mary and Gustave Kellner Prize at the National Association of Women Artists Annual Exhibition at the National Academy of Design in New York, and in 1966 the Sculpture Prize at the Fiftieth Anniversary Exhibition, Philadelphia Art Alliance in Philadelphia. She exhibited mainly in New York and New Jersey and was married to author and editor Walter Teller.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The papers of printmaker and sculptor Jane Teller measure 8.3 linear feet and date from 1911 to 1991. The papers include biographical materials, correspondence, business records, notes, writings, three sketchbooks, sketches and prints, five scrapbooks, printed material, subject files, photographs, sound and video recordings, and motion picture film.

Biographical material includes a birth certificate, school work, and passports. General correspondence includes letters from several artists including Rhys Caparn, Sue Fuller and Lee Gatch, and from art galleries, including the Museum of Modern Art, Albright-Knox Art Gallery and the Whitney Museum of American Art. Additional correspondence is found in the Subject Files.

Business records include an account book, lists of expenses and prices of art works, and sales records. Notes and writings include Teller's notes about art and travel, artists' statements, autobiographical writings, and a compilation of many artists' statements regarding "The Nine Bean Question."
Artwork includes three sketchbooks, 30 sketches and three prints primarily depicting nature and sculpture designs.

Five scrapbooks contain clippings, exbition announcements and catalogs. Additional printed material includes magazines, exhibition announcements and catalogs, a booklet by Teller entitled Art, Age and the River, published posthumously by her husband, and a manuscript of Poems or Poetic Expressions of Sculptors, collected by L. Lamis.

Subject files are arranged by name or subject and may contain letters, photographs, and printed material. Many of the files focus on galleries and museums, including the Montclair Art Museum, the Newark Museum, Noyes Museum, Parma Gallery, the Princeton Gallery of Fine Art and the Squibb Gallery. There are also subject files for associations, travel, projects, and colleagues including Margaret K. Johnson, Reuben Kadish, Ibram Lassaw, Aaron Siskind and Dorothy Dehner.
Photographs and slides depict Teller, her friends, works, gallery installations, and travels. Also included are photographs of trees, bark, and other natural formations used by Teller in her work.

The audio-visual materials include several sound recordings, videocassettes and 16 mm motion pictures. The videocassettes include television programs in which Teller, printmaker Judith Brodsky and actor Harry Hamlin are interviewed, a retrospective at Skidmore College and a film featuring Teller speaking for the National Council on Aging. Sound recordings include two interviews and a "Talk on Malta" by Teller and Joan Needham. The 16 mm tapes are of Teller at her first Parma Gallery show.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged as 11 series. Records are generally arranged by material type and chronologically thereafter.

list.item: Series 8: Printed Material, 1957-1991 (Boxes 2-3 and 9; 0.6 linear feet)

controlaccess.head: Names and Subject Terms
controlaccess.p: This collection is indexed in the online catalog of the Archives of American Art under the following terms:

controlaccess.head: Names:
controlaccess.corpname: Museum of Modern Art (New York, N.Y.)

scopecontent.p: Biographical material dates from 1911 to 1985 and is comprised of a birth certificate, passports, report cards and resumes.

Correspondence dates from 1956 to 1991 and includes letters from Rhys Caparn, Sue Fuller and Lee Gatch. A substantial amount of correspondence is from art galleries, including the Museum of Modern Art, Albright-Knox Art Gallery (Buffalo, New York) and the Whitney Museum of American Art.
Business Records date from 1961 to 1990 and include an account book, lists of expenses, prices of art works, receipts, sales records and travel receipts.

did.unittitle: Lists of Works and Price Lists, 1976-1988

scopecontent.p: Notes date from 1960 to 1987 and include notes about frames, wood finishes and travel ideas, a notebook from a Renaissance architecture class and notes for an essay about Zoltan Buki.

did.unittitle: Notes for Zoltan Buki Essay, undated
Lecture Notes: Talk on Malta, undated

scopecontent.p: Writings date from 1960 to 1989 and primarily consist of artists' staements and autobiographical writings on Teller's thought and dreams, and a compilation of many artists' statements regarding "The Nine Bean Question."
Artwork dates from circa 1950s and includes three sketchbooks, thirty sketches and three prints. The artwork depicts nature and sculpture designs.
Five scrapbooks date from 1948 to 1990 and contain clippings, exbition announcements and catalogs.

Printed material dates from 1957 to 1991 and includes 8 issues of the magazine Scrap, exhibition announcements and catalogs for Teller and others, a booklet by Teller entitled Art, Age and the River, published posthumously by her husband, and a manuscript of Poems or Poetic Expressions of Sculptors, collected by L. Lamis.

did.unittitle: Exhibition Announcements and Catalogs for Others, 1964-1989
Exhibition Announcements and Catalogs for Others, 1964-1989
Booklets: Art, Age, and the River, 1991
Oversized Clippings and "9 Evenings" Performance Schedule, 1966

scopecontent.p: Subject Files date from 1951 to 1990 and contain letters, photographs, and printed material about galleries and museums, including the Montclair Art Museum, the Newark Museum, Noyes Museum, Parma Gallery, the Princeton Gallery of Fine Art and the Squibb Gallery. The collection contains subject files with materials from colleagues Margaret K. Johnson, Reuben Kadish, Ibram Lassaw, Aaron Siskind and Dorothy Dehner. Other subjects include Tellers' various travels and projects.

did.unittitle: New Jersey Council on the Arts, 1980-1982
New Jersey State Council on the Arts Fellowship, 1984-1986
Sculpture for Schools for the Handicapped in Mercer and Ocean Counties, N.J., 1979-1983

scopecontent.p: Photographs and slides date from 1934 to 1985 and depict Teller, her friends, works, gallery installations, and travels to Corfu, England, France, Italy, Japan, Malta, Mexico, North Africa, Spain, California and Utah. Also included are studies of trees, bark, and other natural formations used by Teller in her work.

arrangement.p: The end of the series (folders 15-19) are slide cases. They have been placed at the back of box 8 for preservation purposes.

Oversized Trip to Corfu (Olive Trees) Photographs,1970

scopecontent.p: Audio-visual materials date from 1952 to 1989 and include sound recordings, videocassettes and 16 mm motion picture filmCaparn, Rhys, 1909-. The videocassettes are of the "State of the Arts" television programs (May and November 1989), in which Teller, printmaker Judith Brodsky and actor Harry Hamlin are interviewed, a retrospective at Skidmore College and a film entitled "The Sixth Sense" in which Teller speaks for the National Council on Aging. The audiocassettes include a "Talk on Malta" by Teller and Joan Needham and interviews for New Jersey Public TV and Princeton, New Jersey WPRB. The 16 mm tapes are of Teller at her first Parma Gallery show in 1952.
